channel.title: Nature
channel.description: Nature is the foremost international weekly scientific journal in the world and is the flagship journal for Nature Portfolio. It publishes the finest peer-reviewed research in all fields of science and technology on the basis of its originality, importance, interdisciplinary interest, timeliness, accessibility, elegance and surprising conclusions. Nature publishes landmark papers, award winning news, leading comment and expert opinion on important, topical scientific news and events that enable readers to share the latest discoveries in science and evolve the discussion amongst the global scientific community.
channel.dc:rights: © 2023 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.
channel.prism:copyright: © 2023 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.

Carbon’s social cost can’t be retrofitted to water
item.dc:title: Carbon’s social cost can’t be retrofitted to water
item.dc:creator: Sarah Wheeler
Claudia Ringler
Dustin Garrick

item.content:encoded:

The Bayh–Dole Coalition responds
item.dc:title: The Bayh–Dole Coalition responds
item.dc:creator: Joseph P. Allen

item.title: Reform economics for managing global water supply
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01563-3

Reform economics for managing global water supply
item.dc:title: Reform economics for managing global water supply
item.dc:creator: Edward B. Barbier

item.title: Why the fate of Turkish higher education hinges on the country’s general election
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01548-2

Abolishing the council that controls the universities would allow higher education to finally blossom.
item.dc:title: Why the fate of Turkish higher education hinges on the country’s general election
item.dc:creator: Taner Bilgiç

item.title: Proposed EU data laws leave researchers out in the cold
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01572-2

Some scientists say the European Commission’s Data Act would favour businesses in its aim to expand access rights to big data, and fear that publicly funded science will suffer.
item.dc:title: Proposed EU data laws leave researchers out in the cold
item.dc:creator: Nic Fleming

item.title: Mimicking of human skin to build wearable sensors
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01553-5

Yichen Cai creates thin, flexible devices that could have myriad uses, from wearable blood-pressure monitors to touch sensors for robots.
item.dc:title: Mimicking of human skin to build wearable sensors
item.dc:creator: Linda Nordling

item.title: Ethics in outer space: can we make interplanetary exploration just?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01551-7

The prospect of settling the Moon, Mars and elsewhere requires urgent conversations about issues such as labour and reproductive rights far from Earth.
item.dc:title: Ethics in outer space: can we make interplanetary exploration just?
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Witze

item.title: NIH reinstates grant for controversial coronavirus research
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01566-0

EcoHealth Alliance lost the funding during the Trump administration but can now proceed with its research — under extensive restrictions.
item.dc:title: NIH reinstates grant for controversial coronavirus research
item.dc:creator: Max Kozlov

item.title: Time tracking for early-career researchers: a practical guide
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01552-6

Time management isn’t taught at graduate school, but a better understanding of how you pass the hours can help you achieve your goals.
item.dc:title: Time tracking for early-career researchers: a practical guide
item.dc:creator: Linda Nordling

item.title: Author Correction: Apolipoprotein E controls cerebrovascular integrity via cyclophilin A
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06118-0

Author Correction: Apolipoprotein E controls cerebrovascular integrity via cyclophilin A
item.dc:title: Author Correction: Apolipoprotein E controls cerebrovascular integrity via cyclophilin A

item.title: Saudi universities entice top scientists to switch affiliations — sometimes with cash
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01523-x

Some institutions arrange for highly cited researchers to change their main affiliations, which boosts their position in global university rankings.
item.dc:title: Saudi universities entice top scientists to switch affiliations — sometimes with cash
item.dc:creator: Michele Catanzaro

item.title: WHO declares end to COVID-19’s emergency phase
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01559-z

The pandemic has been on a “downward trend”, but the risk of new variants remains, says WHO director-general.
item.dc:title: WHO declares end to COVID-19’s emergency phase
item.dc:creator: Mariana Lenharo

item.title: Rynnden has invited you to a scheduled meeting
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01407-0

In space, no one can hear you screen.
item.dc:title: Rynnden has invited you to a scheduled meeting
item.dc:creator: Pauline Barmby

item.title: CDC director Rochelle Walensky is leaving her post
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01567-z

Chief of US public-health agency announced her departure as COVID-19 emergency declarations end.
item.dc:title: CDC director Rochelle Walensky is leaving her post
item.dc:creator: Traci Watson
Max Kozlov

item.title: What Russia’s continued participation in the ISS means for science
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01558-0

The nation’s support for the International Space Station until 2028 is a relief for international scientists who depend on it for their research.
item.dc:title: What Russia’s continued participation in the ISS means for science
item.dc:creator: Layal Liverpool

item.title: Shielding science from politics: how Joe Biden’s research integrity drive is faring
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01396-0

Representatives of US whistleblower organisations deliver their verdict on a strategy to protect federal scientists and their research.
item.dc:title: Shielding science from politics: how Joe Biden’s research integrity drive is faring
item.dc:creator: Adam Levy

item.title: Author Correction: CFTR function, pathology and pharmacology at single-molecule resolution
item.content:encoded:

Author Correction: CFTR function, pathology and pharmacology at single-molecule resolution

Daniel S. Terry

item.title: Author Correction: Population dynamics of head-direction neurons during drift and reorientation
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06126-0

Author Correction: Population dynamics of head-direction neurons during drift and reorientation
item.dc:title: Author Correction: Population dynamics of head-direction neurons during drift and reorientation
item.dc:creator: Zaki Ajabi
Alexandra T. Keinath
Xue-Xin Wei
Mark P. Brandon

item.title: How generative AI is building better antibodies
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01516-w

Language models similar to those behind ChatGPT have been used to improve antibody therapies against COVID-19, Ebola and other viruses.
item.dc:title: How generative AI is building better antibodies
item.dc:creator: Ewen Callaway

item.title: Wuhan market samples fail to shed further light on COVID origins
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01483-2

New analysis of genomic data from market swabs highlights their limitations.
item.dc:title: Wuhan market samples fail to shed further light on COVID origins
item.dc:creator: Dyani Lewis

item.title: Hard feelings over mission change for NASA’s Pluto spacecraft
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01530-y

US space agency plans to shift the New Horizons planetary probe to studying heliophysics, and some scientists don’t agree.
item.dc:title: Hard feelings over mission change for NASA’s Pluto spacecraft
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Witze

item.title: Daily briefing: World’s first vaccine for RSV approved
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01561-5

FDA approves GSK’s vaccine Arexvy against respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) for older people. Plus, prehistoric pendant’s DNA reveals the person who held it and investment in diseases that mostly affect women could reap big rewards.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: World’s first vaccine for RSV approved
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: How a simple idea to share lab materials led to a circular-economy movement in science
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01557-1

Garry Cooper’s sustainability business has grown to help thousands of people conduct more efficient research.
item.dc:title: How a simple idea to share lab materials led to a circular-economy movement in science
item.dc:creator: Rachael Pells

item.title: GISAID in crisis: can the controversial COVID genome database survive?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01517-9

The most popular repository for sharing SARS-CoV-2 sequence data has come under increasing scrutiny. Scientists and funders around the world must now consider what lies ahead for the open sharing of genome data.
item.dc:title: GISAID in crisis: can the controversial COVID genome database survive?
item.dc:creator: Mariana Lenharo

item.title: New cellular ‘organelle’ discovered inside fruit-fly intestines
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01518-8

Fruit-fly cells use previously unknown complex cellular structures to store phosphate, a molecule essential to life
item.dc:title: New cellular ‘organelle’ discovered inside fruit-fly intestines
item.dc:creator: Gemma Conroy

item.title: Alzheimer’s drug donanemab: what promising trial means for treatments
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01537-5

Results suggest that the amyloid-targeting drug candidate slows cognitive decline in some people, but questions remain over its potential side effects.
item.dc:title: Alzheimer’s drug donanemab: what promising trial means for treatments
item.dc:creator: Sara Reardon

item.title: Publisher Correction: 2D fin field-effect transistors integrated with epitaxial high-k gate oxide
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06093-6

Publisher Correction: 2D fin field-effect transistors integrated with epitaxial high-k gate oxide
item.dc:title: Publisher Correction: 2D fin field-effect transistors integrated with epitaxial high-k gate oxide

item.title: Old and new cannabis compounds are found in an African herb
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01462-7

A plant used as medicine by South African peoples could be a source of some of the ingredients in the marijuana plant.
item.dc:title: Old and new cannabis compounds are found in an African herb

item.title: Wearable sensor gives a glimpse of ‘invisible’ light
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01460-9

A device that transforms infrared light into a visible image could be used for anti-surveillance purposes.
item.dc:title: Wearable sensor gives a glimpse of ‘invisible’ light

item.title: Timing matters for COVID vaccine effectiveness
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01463-6

Younger and older people gained greater protection if they had their jabs in the middle of the day.
item.dc:title: Timing matters for COVID vaccine effectiveness

item.title: Refugee kids find more friends in diverse classrooms
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01459-2

Children living in Germany who had fled their home countries faced less rejection if their classes were ethnically mixed.
item.dc:title: Refugee kids find more friends in diverse classrooms

item.title: They’re a couple: JWST is first to spot pair of mysterious ‘Y dwarfs’
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01461-8

Two extremely cool examples of ‘failed stars’ called brown dwarfs are found orbiting each other.
item.dc:title: They’re a couple: JWST is first to spot pair of mysterious ‘Y dwarfs’

item.title: Menopause and women’s health: why science needs to catch up
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01525-9

A focus on women’s health research, and the star caught in the act of devouring a planet.
item.dc:title: Menopause and women’s health: why science needs to catch up
item.dc:creator: Nick Petrić Howe
Shamini Bundell

item.title: Constrained C<sub>2</sub> adsorbate orientation enables CO-to-acetate electroreduction
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05918-8

A study using a copper-in-silver dilute alloy catalyst in a high-pressure gas flow reactor reports highly selective electrosynthesis of acetate from carbon monoxide.
item.dc:title: Constrained C<sub>2</sub> adsorbate orientation enables CO-to-acetate electroreduction

item.title: A phosphate-sensing organelle regulates phosphate and tissue homeostasis
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06039-y

PXo bodies, non-canonical multilamellar organelles, serve as a reservoir for intracellular inorganic phosphate and are a critical regulator of both cytosolic phosphate levels and tissue homeostasis.
item.dc:title: A phosphate-sensing organelle regulates phosphate and tissue homeostasis
item.dc:creator: Chiwei Xu
Jun Xu
Hong-Wen Tang
Maria Ericsson
Jui-Hsia Weng
Jonathan DiRusso

Norbert Perrimon

item.title: The lunar solid inner core and the mantle overturn
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05935-7

By combining geophysical and geodetic constraints for different models of the internal structure of the Moon, evidence is provided supporting the lunar mantle overturn scenario and the existence of a solid inner core.
item.dc:title: The lunar solid inner core and the mantle overturn
item.dc:creator: Arthur Briaud
Clément Ganino
Agnès Fienga
Anthony Mémin
Nicolas Rambaux

item.title: Testosterone histories from tusks reveal woolly mammoth musth episodes
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06020-9

Comparisons of steroid hormone concentrations in dentin samples from fossil mammoth tusks with those from a modern elephant tusk provide evidence of periodic increases in testosterone in the male mammoth characteristic of musth episodes.
item.dc:title: Testosterone histories from tusks reveal woolly mammoth musth episodes
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Cherney
Daniel C. Fisher
Richard J. Auchus
Adam N. Rountrey

Gennady G. Boeskorov
Sergey L. Vartanyan
Alexei N. Tikhonov

item.title: Electrically driven amplified spontaneous emission from colloidal quantum dots
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05855-6

Colloidal quantum dot devices demonstrating electrically pumped amplified spontaneous emission are described, showing strong, broadband optical gain and bright edge emission, opening the path to solution-processable laser diodes.
item.dc:title: Electrically driven amplified spontaneous emission from colloidal quantum dots
item.dc:creator: Namyoung Ahn
Clément Livache
Valerio Pinchetti
Heeyoung Jung
Ho Jin
Donghyo Hahm
Young-Shin Park
Victor I. Klimov

item.title: Ancient human DNA recovered from a Palaeolithic pendant
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06035-2

A non-destructive DNA isolation method for the stepwise release of DNA trapped in ancient tooth and bone artefacts is developed.
item.dc:title: Ancient human DNA recovered from a Palaeolithic pendant

item.title: Reappraising the palaeobiology of Australopithecus
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05957-1

This Review examines the palaeobiology of Australopithecus in terms of morphology, phylogeny, diet, tool use, locomotor behaviour and other characteristics, and considers the role of this genus of hominins in human evolution.
item.dc:title: Reappraising the palaeobiology of Australopithecus
item.dc:creator: Zeresenay Alemseged

item.title: Helical polymers for dissymmetric circularly polarized light imaging
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05877-0

We report a simple method to fabricate chiroptical flexible layers via supramolecular helical ordering of conjugated polymer chains, providing direct, scalable realization of on-chip detection of the spin degree of freedom of photons.
item.dc:title: Helical polymers for dissymmetric circularly polarized light imaging
item.dc:creator: Inho Song
Jaeyong Ahn
Hyungju Ahn
Sang Hyuk Lee
Jianguo Mei
Nicholas A. Kotov
Joon Hak Oh

item.title: Structural atlas of a human gut crassvirus
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06019-2

A cryo-electron microscopy reconstruction of the virus ΦcrAss001 provides insights into the functions of the viral gene products in capsid assembly and infection.
item.dc:title: Structural atlas of a human gut crassvirus
item.dc:creator: Oliver W. Bayfield
Andrey N. Shkoporov
Natalya Yutin

Alfred A. Antson

item.title: Ligand and G-protein selectivity in the κ-opioid receptor
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06030-7

Active-state structures of the κ-opioid receptor in complexes with the G-protein heterotrimers Gi1, GoA, Gz and Gg provide insights into the actions of hallucinogenic opioids and G-protein-coupling specificity at the κ-opioid receptor.
item.dc:title: Ligand and G-protein selectivity in the κ-opioid receptor
item.dc:creator: Jianming Han

item.title: Cortico-cortical feedback engages active dendrites in visual cortex
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06007-6

Feedback influence from a higher visual area to primary visual cortex in mice engages nonlinear dendritic integration.
item.dc:title: Cortico-cortical feedback engages active dendrites in visual cortex
item.dc:creator: Mehmet Fişek
Dustin Herrmann
Alexander Egea-Weiss
Matilda Cloves
Lisa Bauer
Tai-Ying Lee

Michael Häusser

item.title: Targeting PD-L2–RGMb overcomes microbiome-related immunotherapy resistance
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06026-3

Interactions between programmed death ligand 2 (PD-L2) and its binding partner RGMb are downregulated by the gut microbiota, a mechanism that may be exploited to enhance the efficacy of PD-1-based cancer immunotherapies.
item.dc:title: Targeting PD-L2–RGMb overcomes microbiome-related immunotherapy resistance
item.dc:creator: Joon Seok Park
Francesca S. Gazzaniga
Meng Wu

item.title: Photo-induced high-temperature ferromagnetism in YTiO<sub>3</sub>
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05853-8

All-optical, mode-selective manipulation of the crystal lattice can be used to enhance and stabilize ferromagnetism in YTiO3 well above its equilibrium ordering temperature and for many nanoseconds, enabling dynamic engineering of practically useful non-equilibrium functionalities in fluctuating electronic systems.
item.dc:title: Photo-induced high-temperature ferromagnetism in YTiO<sub>3</sub>
item.dc:creator: A. S. Disa

A. Cavalleri

item.title: Concurrent self-assembly of RGB microLEDs for next-generation displays
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05889-w

A new transfer method for microLEDs fabrication based on fluidic self-assembly technology combining magnetic and dielectrophoresis forces is described, achieving a very high simultaneous RGB LED transfer yield and over large areas.
item.dc:title: Concurrent self-assembly of RGB microLEDs for next-generation displays
item.dc:creator: Wonjae Chang

item.title: Structural evidence for intermediates during O<sub>2</sub> formation in photosystem II
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06038-z

Using serial femtosecond X-ray cystallography, we provide structural insights into the final reaction step of Kok’s photosynthetic water oxidation cycle, specifically the S3→[S4]→S0 transition where O2 is formed.
item.dc:title: Structural evidence for intermediates during O<sub>2</sub> formation in photosystem II

item.title: Glioblastoma remodelling of human neural circuits decreases survival
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06036-1

High-grade gliomas functionally remodel neural circuits in the human brain, promoting tumour progression and impairing cognition.
item.dc:title: Glioblastoma remodelling of human neural circuits decreases survival

item.title: An infrared transient from a star engulfing a planet
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05842-x

Observations of ZTF SLRN-2020, a short-lived optical outburst in the Galactic disk accompanied by bright, long-lived infrared emission, show that the resulting light curve and spectra are consistent with the signatures of a planet being engulfed by its host star.
item.dc:title: An infrared transient from a star engulfing a planet

item.title: Learnable latent embeddings for joint behavioural and neural analysis
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06031-6

A new encoding method, CEBRA, jointly uses behavioural and neural data in a (supervised) hypothesis- or (self-supervised) discovery-driven manner to produce both consistent and high-performance latent spaces.
item.dc:title: Learnable latent embeddings for joint behavioural and neural analysis
item.dc:creator: Steffen Schneider
Jin Hwa Lee
Mackenzie Weygandt Mathis

item.title: The electron–proton bottleneck of photosynthetic oxygen evolution
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06008-5

Microsecond infrared spectroscopy together with quantum chemistry reveal the rate-determining proton and electron movements and identify an oxygen-radical state of the manganese cluster as the S4 state.
item.dc:title: The electron–proton bottleneck of photosynthetic oxygen evolution
item.dc:creator: Paul Greife
Matthias Schönborn
Matteo Capone
Ricardo Assunção
Daniele Narzi
Leonardo Guidoni
Holger Dau

item.title: Complete integration of carbene-transfer chemistry into biosynthesis
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06027-2

The α-diazoester azaserine can be produced by Streptomyces albus engineered with a biosynthetic gene cluster and act as the carbene precursor for coupling with intracellularly produced styrene to generate unnatural amino acids containing a cyclopropyl group.
item.dc:title: Complete integration of carbene-transfer chemistry into biosynthesis
item.dc:creator: Jing Huang
Andrew Quest
Pablo Cruz-Morales
Kai Deng
Jose Henrique Pereira
Devon Van Cura
Ramu Kakumanu
Edward E. K. Baidoo
Qingyun Dan
Yan Chen
Christopher J. Petzold
Trent R. Northen
Paul D. Adams
Douglas S. Clark
Emily P. Balskus
John F. Hartwig
Aindrila Mukhopadhyay
Jay D. Keasling

item.title: Particle–hole symmetry protects spin-valley blockade in graphene quantum dots
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05953-5

Bilayer graphene allows the realization of electron–hole double-quantum dots that exhibit near-perfect particle–hole symmetry, in which transport occurs via the creation and annihilation of single electron–hole pairs with opposite quantum numbers.
item.dc:title: Particle–hole symmetry protects spin-valley blockade in graphene quantum dots
item.dc:creator: L. Banszerus
S. Möller
K. Hecker
E. Icking
K. Watanabe
T. Taniguchi
F. Hassler
C. Volk
C. Stampfer

item.title: How thought itself can drive tumour growth
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01387-1

Tumour cells can form connections with neurons in the brain. Examination of a variety of types of evidence concerning human brain cancer sheds light on how these tumour–neuron interactions affect cognition and survival times.
item.dc:title: How thought itself can drive tumour growth
item.dc:creator: George M. Ibrahim
Michael D. Taylor

item.title: Ancient woman’s DNA recovered from a 20,000-year-old pendant
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01342-0

An innovative method was used to obtain a woman’s rich DNA record from a 20,000-year-old pendant found in Siberia, providing the first direct genetic evidence for the identity of an individual who handled an object in the deep past.
item.dc:title: Ancient woman’s DNA recovered from a 20,000-year-old pendant

item.title: How menopause reshapes the brain
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01474-3

Researchers are starting to learn how the early stages of menopause affect brain health — and what that could mean for treatment.
item.dc:title: How menopause reshapes the brain
item.dc:creator: Heidi Ledford

item.title: Phosphate-storing organelle discovered in fruit flies
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01410-5

Inorganic phosphate is an essential mineral for cellular metabolism and signalling. It emerges that a fruit-fly organelle can store this chemical in the form of phospholipids, releasing it in times of need.
item.dc:title: Phosphate-storing organelle discovered in fruit flies
item.dc:creator: Emily Strachan
Irene Miguel-Aliaga

item.title: Planet swallowed after venturing too close to its star
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01385-3

An outburst of radiation offers direct evidence that a star has consumed a giant planet. But not every planet ends up as a stellar host’s snack — the star’s properties, and its interactions with the planet, have to be just right.
item.dc:title: Planet swallowed after venturing too close to its star
item.dc:creator: Smadar Naoz

item.title: Women’s health: end the disparity in funding
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01472-5

Funding for research on women’s health is still a fraction of that available for men’s health.
item.dc:title: Women’s health: end the disparity in funding

item.title: ‘Einstein’ telescope high on Europe’s astronomy wish list
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01524-w

A massive gravitational-wave detector and the new solar telescope are among the priorities on funders’ latest roadmap.
item.dc:title: ‘Einstein’ telescope high on Europe’s astronomy wish list
item.dc:creator: Katharine Sanderson

item.title: ‘A good day’: FDA approves world’s first RSV vaccine
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01529-5

Green light from US regulatory agency for GSK’s jab caps off a decades-long quest.
item.dc:title: ‘A good day’: FDA approves world’s first RSV vaccine
item.dc:creator: Myriam Vidal Valero

item.title: Clues to how water splits during photosynthesis
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01388-0

The tools of crystallography, spectroscopy and quantum chemistry are pulling back the curtain on photosynthesis, probing previously elusive catalytic intermediates that arise when water splits to form oxygen.
item.dc:title: Clues to how water splits during photosynthesis
item.dc:creator: Dimitrios A. Pantazis

item.title: Unlocking the mysteries of the brain’s neocortex
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01531-x

Entrepreneur Jeff Hawkins explains how our knowledge of the brain can help us to better understand artificial intelligence.
item.dc:title: Unlocking the mysteries of the brain’s neocortex
item.dc:creator: Dom Byrne

item.title: Women’s health research lacks funding — these charts show how
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01475-2

Conditions that affect women more than men garner less funding. But boosting investment could reap big rewards.
item.dc:title: Women’s health research lacks funding — these charts show how
item.dc:creator: Kerri Smith

item.title: Prehistoric pendant’s DNA reveals the person who held it
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01482-3

An innovative method reveals that an ancient trinket was handled by a woman some 20,000 years ago.
item.dc:title: Prehistoric pendant’s DNA reveals the person who held it
item.dc:creator: Elissa Welle

item.title: Structure of the most abundant human gut virus
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01336-y

Crassviruses are the most abundant, and among the most genetically diverse, viruses found in the human gut. New structural information about these viruses has shed light on the functions of previously uncharacterized proteins in virus-particle assembly and infection.
item.dc:title: Structure of the most abundant human gut virus

item.title: Bright light coaxed from electrically driven quantum dots
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01386-2

Nanocrystals made from a semiconducting material have been shown to emit intense light when excited with an electric current. The technology could be used to build a type of laser that is more versatile than those in general use.
item.dc:title: Bright light coaxed from electrically driven quantum dots
item.dc:creator: Thilo Stöferle
Rainer F. Mahrt

item.title: Daily briefing: Menopause is driven by the brain, not just the ovaries
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01534-8

The neurological causes of menopause, the month’s best science images and an AI-powered brain scan that can decode imagined speech.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Menopause is driven by the brain, not just the ovaries
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: Is the world ready for ChatGPT therapists?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01473-4

The current landscape of mobile mental-health apps is the result of a 70-year search to automate therapy. Now, advanced AIs pose fresh ethical questions.
item.dc:title: Is the world ready for ChatGPT therapists?
item.dc:creator: Ian Graber-Stiehl

item.title: Dad and Ick
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01405-2

Machine learning.
item.dc:title: Dad and Ick
item.dc:creator: Susan Taitel

item.title: Researchers who agree to manipulate citations are more likely to get their papers published
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01532-w

Data suggest that these researchers are more willing to publish in journals that participate in such coercion.
item.dc:title: Researchers who agree to manipulate citations are more likely to get their papers published
item.dc:creator: Dalmeet Singh Chawla

item.title: Brain dynamics uncovered using a machine-learning algorithm
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01339-9

CEBRA is a machine-learning method that can be used to compress time series in a way that reveals otherwise hidden structures in the variability of the data. It excels at processing behavioural and neural data recorded simultaneously, and it can decode activity from the visual cortex of the mouse brain to reconstruct a viewed video.
item.dc:title: Brain dynamics uncovered using a machine-learning algorithm

item.title: Algorithm for Optimized mRNA Design Improves Stability and Immunogenicity
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06127-z

Algorithm for Optimized mRNA Design Improves Stability and Immunogenicity
item.dc:title: Algorithm for Optimized mRNA Design Improves Stability and Immunogenicity

item.title: From the archive: socially responsible physicists, and aimless wandering in circles
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01384-4

Snippets from Nature’s past.
